item.dc:creator: westi

Replying to Otto42:

When were nonces added? Perhaps the version he's using is pre-nonce?

The relavent ticket is #3973 which was fixed for 2.2 , 2.1.3, 2.0.10

item.title: Ticket #4361 (Notify user of theme using deprecated code) created
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description:
Suggestion: In the event that a theme uses "deprecated" code (basically anything in deprecated.php), set some sort of flag to notify the user on the main wp-admin screen. This would tell him that he needs to look for an upgraded version of his theme.

Further suggestion: Keep trak of which deprecated functions his theme is using and tell him, along with suggested alternatives (and appropriate codex links), in case he wants to update the theme himself.

item.title: Ticket #4051 (blogroll not functional for internal links) updated
item.dc:creator: Otto42
item.description:
Note for anybody else who wants to know:

The fix for this is in bookmark-template.php. Remove this code from the _walk_bookmarks() function: 

if ( !empty($bookmark->link_url) )
	$the_link = clean_url($bookmark->link_url);

And all your Bookmark URLs will then go unmolested.

item.title: Ticket #4360 (Allow commenting without giving an email address, but still requiring ...) created
item.dc:creator: jameslab6
item.description: There is a Discussion option "Comment author must fill out name and e-mail". I want every commenter to have a name, but I don't care about them giving an email address (nobody gives real addresses anyway). So I think these two requirements should be decoupled.

item.title: Ticket #4359 (Remove author dropdown from Manage Posts) updated
item.dc:creator: westi
item.description: Owner, Status changed

item.title: remove-authors.diff attached to Ticket #4359
item.dc:creator: westi
item.description: Patch to remove the authors dropdown and move the action to a better place.

item.title: Ticket #4359 (Remove author dropdown from Manage Posts) created
item.dc:creator: westi
item.description:
The consensus on #3120 was that Manage Posts should not have an author dropdown as it didn't scale well for blogs with a large number of authors.

The reasoning was that we have a good UI method of accessing this view already via the [users.php page ​http://trac.wordpress.org/ticket/3120#comment:8]

Therefore we should remove the authors dropdown that currently appears on Manage -> Posts.

Also the action for adding your own filters has moved to be above the page heading which makes a plugin place it's UI in the wrong place.

See: ​http://nslog.com/2007/05/25/wordpress_22_changes_category_order_behavior

The tricky part here is UI... get those gears churning.

item.title: Ticket #4332 (Unusable comment error pages) updated

item.description: We have the comment form hook. We could pass on an error number that is handled by the comment form hook and translated into a user-friendly message. We could also put in some JS that does client-side validation.

item.title: Ticket #4340 (Hooks to disable various features of admin) updated
item.dc:creator: oaoao
item.description:
Cc changed

@cpoteet: No, actually customizing the components, not just the menu. But that's a nice plugin I didn't know about!

@matt & pixline: CSS has definite limitations. It's also not always as simple as burying something. Try doing display:none on the floating right pieces for example. Or what if I want to deny users from using something very specific in the admin interface? With CSS, everything is still accessible via viewing source or disabling CSS. What if I want to remove a certain js piece? I'm loading some heavy js framework and am feeling the bloat. What if I want to push some content between two pieces? One plugin author resorted to using js to push the content in. What if load order matters?

Most of this is possible to some extent, but it gets hackish quickly. I'd like my CMS work to be forwards compatible as a plugin and without having to modify the core code. One wouldn't expect theme authors to rely completely on CSS, so why on the admin side?

In addition, I think this feature would remain pretty lightweight and I can't think of a reason it would impact anything old (Said with great humility, correct me if I'm wrong)?

item.title: Ticket #4340 (Hooks to disable various features of admin) updated
item.dc:creator: pixline
item.description: CSS is the best way and it's easily reversible, but I think that a bunch of new hooks to disable or tweak some interface (or some part of it) would make easier using WP as a CMS, reorganizing menus and logical areas according to real needs instead of WP core logic. Also, in some case, would be really nice to drop some DB calls and free memory and resources for - in my real case - a whole DB included into WP interface. +1 for hooks, +1 for WP as a development framework.

item.title: Ticket #4352 (Reinstate 'Write Post' heading under Write->Post for consistency) updated
item.dc:creator: rob1n
item.description:
Keywords, Owner, Status changed

Thus leads to the debate of simplicity or consistency.

Simplicity in the fact that the Write Post screen is the default one, and for some the <h2> would add clutter, whereas on the Write Page it's not the post one, so better to alert the user to this.

Consistency in the fact that both should have the <h2>'s.

I would go to the latter (consistency) choice if I had to decide, but IMO it doesn't make much of a difference.

item.title: Ticket #4353 (Users with edit_posts capability can see everyone's comments, IPs, and ...) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
Status, Description, Summary, Owner, Type, Severity changed

edit_posts is used to control comment editing, specifically, but viewing, generally. If you have the edit_posts capability, you'll be able to view all comments, but only be able to edit the ones on your posts.

Contributors won't be able to view any comments or edit any. The only default role affected here is "Author."

What you're advocating is a change in functionality, so I'm going to update the ticket to reflect that.

item.title: Ticket #4352 (Reinstate 'Write Post' heading under Write->Post for consistency) updated
item.dc:creator: johnbillion
item.description: Keywords changed

item.title: Ticket #4353 (Users with edit_posts capability can see everyone's comments, IPs, and ...) created
item.dc:creator: idahofallzcom
item.description:
I've been fighting this problem for several weeks now. I've updated Role Manager to the new one (not the owen winkler version), and it also does not fix the problem.

Everyone above subscriber can click "comments" and see everyone's comments, email addresses, and IP addresses. This is a very BAD thing.

From what I've read, edit_posts for contributor and authors is supposed to only display the person's own comments. However this function is broken somehow and instead anyone can see everyone else's comments.

Mark Jaquith says:

It wasn't designed to restrict people with edit_posts from only being able to see the comments they can edit. That would require a slight tweak in the code.

Is this a core code issue or a plugin issue? I think it is core code.

This is very important for me to resolve because i've had to demote everyone on my blog to subscriber, and nobody is able to post anymore.

item.title: Ticket #4351 (Modify Walker_Page to add current_page_tree class for some style) updated

item.title: Ticket #4352 (Reinstate 'Write Post' heading under Write->Post for consistency) created
item.dc:creator: johnbillion
item.description:
Affects versions 2.1 and above.

Go to Write->Post and you'll notice there is no "Write Post" header above the post title input, unlike there is under Write->Page where it says "Write Page".

This has been lost from edit-form-advanced.php somewhere between 2.0 and 2.1. Patch attached to re-instate it for consistency across writing screens.

Happy bank holiday everyone!

item.title: walker-page-tree-diff.txt attached to Ticket #4351
item.dc:creator: ev3rywh3re
item.description: Patch for Walker_Page to add UL class current_page_tree

item.title: Ticket #4351 (Modify Walker_Page to add current_page_tree class for some style) created
item.dc:creator: ev3rywh3re
item.description:
I thought this might be a useful suggestion since CSS has no "parent" selector.

Basically just a slight mod to class Walker_Page that "should" identify the current page location and depth and add a current_page_tree class to the preceding UL. There may be a better implementation, and I did play with adding class levels to the UL(s), but I thought I would keep this simple as a starting point for this ticket.

Here is a sample CSS that seems to work with the attached patch to produce CSS based collapsable lists 

div.sidebar li.page_item ul {
	display: none;
}
div.sidebar li.current_page_item ul {
	display: block;
}
div.sidebar li.current_page_parent ul {
	display: block;
}
div.sidebar li.page_item ul.current_page_tree {
	display: block;
}
div.sidebar li.page_item ul.current_page_tree ul {
	display: block;
}
}}

item.title: Ticket #4350 (Input to bool_from_yn must be normalised) created
item.dc:creator: donncha
item.description: bool_from_yn() expects uppercase characters as input. The following patch adds strtoupper().

item.title: Ticket #4335 (Intrinsic Category Sorting (by ID) Changed in 2.2) updated
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
There's a patch for 2.2. Try that on for size.

I'm leaving this out of the codebase until [4349] gets fixed in trunk, so I can commit fixes to both branches at the same time without risk of regression.

item.title: Ticket #4349 (Category-based permalinks broken in trunk) created
item.dc:creator: markjaquith
item.description:
Category-based permalinks are broken in trunk (as of revision [5570])

Example permalink structure: 

/index.php/%category%/%postname%/

Expected permalink: 

http://example.com/index.php/cat-nicename/post-nicename/

Actual permalink: 

http://example.com/index.php//post-nicename/

Also: typing the expected permalink into the address bar gives 404.
